answer_html: From this table we observe that \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is concave up on \({\color{blue} x \in (-\infty,-\tfrac{5}{2})}\) andconcave down on \({\color{Orange} x \in (-\tfrac{5}{2},0) \cup (0,\infty)}\).
answer_latex:
From this table we observe that $\displaystyle f(x)$ is \textbf{concave
up} on ${\color{blue} x \in (-\infty,-\tfrac{5}{2})}$ and\textbf{concave down} on
${\color{Orange} x \in (-\tfrac{5}{2},0) \cup (0,\infty)}$.
hints_html: What is the sign of \(\displaystyle f''(x)\) when \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is concave up? When \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is concave down?
hints_latex:
What is the sign of $\displaystyle f''(x)$ when $\displaystyle f(x)$ is
concave up? When $\displaystyle f(x)$ is concave down?
hints_raw: What is the sign of <math>\displaystyle f''(x)</math> when <math>\displaystyle f(x)</math> is concave up? When <math>\displaystyle f(x)</math> is concave down?
question: 8 (c)
sols_html:
Where \(\displaystyle f''(x) > 0\), \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is concave up; where \(\displaystyle f''(x) < 0\), \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is concave down. From part (a), we know that

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) &= 18\left(x^{-\frac{5}{7}} - x^{\frac{2}{7}}\right) \\ f''(x) &= 18\left(-\tfrac{5}{7} \cdot x^{-\frac{5}{7} - 1} - \tfrac{2}{7} \cdot x^{\frac{2}{7} - 1} \right) \\ &= 18\left(-\tfrac{5}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}} - \tfrac{2}{7} x^{-\frac{5}{7}}\right) \\ &= \tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}}(-5 - 2x)\end{aligned}\]

Setting \(\displaystyle f''(x) = 0\) and applying the zero product property:

\[\begin{aligned} \tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}}(-5 - 2x) &= 0 \\ {\color{red} \tfrac{18}{7}x^{-\frac{12}{7}}} = 0 \quad -5 - 2x &= 0 \\ -5 - 2x &= 0 \\ x &= -\frac{5}{2}\end{aligned}\]

Note that \(\tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}}\) is never equal to zero on the interval \((-\infty, \infty)\). However, \(\tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}}\) is undefined at \(x = 0\), so \(\displaystyle f''(x)\) does not exist at \(x = 0\).

Therefore, we note that \(\displaystyle f''(x)\) may change sign at \(\displaystyle x = 0\) and \(\displaystyle x = -\tfrac{5}{2}\). We can construct a sign table to organize our calculations:

[c]@llll@ & \(\displaystyle (-\infty, -\tfrac{5}{2})\) & \(\displaystyle (-\tfrac{5}{2}, 0)\) & \(\displaystyle (0, \infty)\)
\(\tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}}\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\)
\(\displaystyle -5 - 2x\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle -\)
\(f''(x) = (\tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}})(-5 - 2x)\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle -\)

From this table we observe that \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is concave up on \({\color{blue} x \in (-\infty,-\tfrac{5}{2})}\) andconcave down on \({\color{Orange} x \in (-\tfrac{5}{2},0) \cup (0,\infty)}\).
sols_latex:
Where $\displaystyle f''(x) > 0$, $\displaystyle f(x)$ is \emph{concave
up}; where $\displaystyle f''(x) < 0$, $\displaystyle f(x)$ is
\emph{concave down}. From
{part
(a)}, we know that

\begin{align*}
f'(x) &= 18\left(x^{-\frac{5}{7}} - x^{\frac{2}{7}}\right)
\\ f''(x) &= 18\left(-\tfrac{5}{7} \cdot x^{-\frac{5}{7} - 1} - \tfrac{2}{7} \cdot x^{\frac{2}{7} - 1} \right)
\\ &= 18\left(-\tfrac{5}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}} - \tfrac{2}{7} x^{-\frac{5}{7}}\right)
\\ &= \tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}}(-5 - 2x)
\end{align*}

Setting $\displaystyle f''(x) = 0$ and applying the zero product
property:

\begin{align*}
\tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}}(-5 - 2x) &= 0
\\ {\color{red} \tfrac{18}{7}x^{-\frac{12}{7}}} = 0 \quad -5 - 2x &= 0
\\ -5 - 2x &= 0
\\ x &= -\frac{5}{2}
\end{align*}

Note that $\tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}}$ is never equal to zero on
the interval $(-\infty, \infty)$. However,
$\tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}}$ is undefined at $x = 0$, so
$\displaystyle f''(x)$ does not exist at $x = 0$.

Therefore, we note that $\displaystyle f''(x)$ may change sign at
$\displaystyle x = 0$ and $\displaystyle x = -\tfrac{5}{2}$. We can
construct a sign table to organize our calculations:

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llll@{}}
& $\displaystyle (-\infty, -\tfrac{5}{2})$ &
$\displaystyle (-\tfrac{5}{2}, 0)$ & $\displaystyle (0, \infty)$\\
$\tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}}$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$
& $\displaystyle +$\\
$\displaystyle -5 - 2x$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle -$ &
$\displaystyle -$\\
$f''(x) = (\tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}})(-5 - 2x)$ & $\displaystyle +$
& $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle -$\\
\end{longtable}

From this table we observe that $\displaystyle f(x)$ is \textbf{concave
up} on ${\color{blue} x \in (-\infty,-\tfrac{5}{2})}$ and\textbf{concave down} on
${\color{Orange} x \in (-\tfrac{5}{2},0) \cup (0,\infty)}$.
sols_raw:
Where <math>\displaystyle f''(x) > 0</math>, <math>\displaystyle f(x)</math> is ''concave up''; where <math>\displaystyle f''(x) < 0</math>, <math>\displaystyle f(x)</math> is ''concave down''. From [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH100/December_2013/Question_08_(a)|part (a)]], we know that

<math>
\begin{align}
f'(x) &= 18\left(x^{-\frac{5}{7}} - x^{\frac{2}{7}}\right)
\\ f''(x) &= 18\left(-\tfrac{5}{7} \cdot x^{-\frac{5}{7} - 1} - \tfrac{2}{7} \cdot x^{\frac{2}{7} - 1} \right)
\\ &= 18\left(-\tfrac{5}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}} - \tfrac{2}{7} x^{-\frac{5}{7}}\right)
\\ &= \tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}}(-5 - 2x)
\end{align}
</math>


Setting <math>\displaystyle f''(x) = 0</math> and applying the zero product property:

<math>
\begin{align}
\tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}}(-5 - 2x) &= 0
\\ {\color{red} \tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}}} = 0 \quad -5 - 2x &= 0
\\ -5 - 2x &= 0
\\ x &= -\frac{5}{2}
\end{align}
</math>

Note that <math>\tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}}</math> is never equal to zero on the interval <math>(-\infty, \infty)</math>. However, <math>\tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}}</math> is undefined at <math> x = 0 </math>, so <math>\displaystyle f''(x)</math> does not exist at <math> x = 0 </math>.

Therefore, we note that <math>\displaystyle f''(x)</math> may change sign at <math>\displaystyle x = 0</math> and <math>\displaystyle x = -\tfrac{5}{2}</math>. We can construct a sign table to organize our calculations:

{| class="wikitable"
|-
| || <math>\displaystyle (-\infty, -\tfrac{5}{2})</math> || <math>\displaystyle (-\tfrac{5}{2}, 0)</math> || <math>\displaystyle (0, \infty)</math>
|-
| <math>\tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}}</math> || <math>\displaystyle+</math> || <math>\displaystyle+</math> || <math>\displaystyle+</math>
|-
| <math>\displaystyle -5 - 2x</math> || <math>\displaystyle+</math> || <math>\displaystyle-</math> || <math>\displaystyle-</math>
|-
| <math>f''(x) = (\tfrac{18}{7} x^{-\frac{12}{7}})(-5 - 2x)</math> || <math>\displaystyle+</math> || <math>\displaystyle-</math> || <math>\displaystyle-</math>
|}

From this table we observe that <math>\displaystyle f(x) </math> is '''concave up''' on <math>{\color{blue} x \in (-\infty,-\tfrac{5}{2})}</math> and '''concave down''' on <math>{\color{Orange} x \in (-\tfrac{5}{2},0) \cup (0, \infty)}</math>.
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answer and show your work. Full simplification of numerical answers is required unless explicitly stated otherwise.

Let \(\displaystyle y = f(x) = 63x^{2/7}-14x^{9/7}\). Determine the intervals where \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is concave up, and the intervals where \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is concave down.
